context.speaker: Richard P. Brown, Jr.
context.text: Now, we submit that with that legislative history of the original limitation upon the power of the federal courts in 1789, the limited expansion of that jurisdiction over the intervening years enacts such as the Interstate Commerce Act.

context.speaker: Robert N. Katz

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Did the Commission -- so how do you really deal this argument?

context.speaker: Robert N. Katz
context.text: They didn't answer them specifically but in so -- the voting and the way they did, they obviously rejected his contentions.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do I understand you to say that -- to Mr. Justice Brennan that if the association had presented this agreement to the Commission, the Commission could or could not in his discretion have considered the validity of it in relation to the antitrust --

context.speaker: Robert N. Katz
context.text: If the Commission determined that it did not affect the competitive relationship, it would --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I beg your pardon?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Why, if it's just delaying why is it so essential?

context.speaker: George N. Hayes
context.text: Because it --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: If I understood you correctly you said that he could have filed this letter with the School Board yesterday and go out take it to the public today.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Is that not what you told Mr. Justice White?

context.speaker: George N. Hayes
context.text: No I don't think those are my words.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well didn't you say, regardless of what the School Board did he could still go to the public with it, if he first gave it to the School Board?

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: I am prepared to answer these questions.

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: So I think that we're properly before this Court and I always want to say as long as we are in the Court, let's have that, but we properly here because counsel has very clearly coupled the one, the adverse pretrial publicity argument to the competency of counsel in failing to do something about the adverse pretrial publicity.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I want to ask you a very question that I try to put as simply and directly as I can.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I don't believe you finished your answer to Justice Marshall's question.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: The record, the trail record did not contain a description or evidence with respect to these television broadcast, is that right?

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: That is right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now the question is, whether the petitioner here was deprived of constitutional right by reason of the court's refusal in collateral proceeding to permit him to present evidence with respect to this prejudicial publicity.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I don't believe that received much attention in your adversary's argument.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Justice Marshall asked you a question along those lines.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I now repeat the question in this form. What is your position with respect to the, to that question, was it or was it not constitutional error for the state court to refuse in these circumstances where a man faces death penalty to admit evidence of the – this allegedly prejudicial pretrial publicity and that sets a legal question to this Court on which I'd like to hear your position?

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: Alright Your Honor my answer is that it was not a denial of due process for this reason that assuming as we must in the posture of this case that there was adverse pretrial publicity that nevertheless the voir dire examination of the jurors establishes beyond any shadow of a doubt that no prejudiced juror was seated in that Jury box.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Kanner may I just --

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: I am Carlisle.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I beg your pardon, excuse me, may I ask you a question on a different subject.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Justice White asked earlier the opinion of your appellate court is not to be read as holding, that because there was no request for a change of venue, the petitioner was not entitled to an evidentiary hearing on these allegations.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, on the premise that's the way it is to be read and I must say it strikes to me that's the way it is to be read, is the State of Florida telling us that this is not an adequate state ground for denying him an evidentiary hearing under your post conviction procedure?

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: Your Honor, I hate this argument by adequate state grounds, but anyway let's go into it a moment.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I have difficulty finding, perhaps you can point out to me.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Under which of any of these or how many of them is there subsumed this point of denial of effective assistance to counsel.

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: Without taking great deal of time Your Honor, I do not know that it is there, I'll leave it to Mr. Kanner to bring it.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The reason I asked, Justice White asking I think both of you and Mr. Kanner earlier, certainly the opinion of Court of Appeals makes no reference to an issue of effective assistance of counsel.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And I just suggest I think it's understandable, that, that point wasn't raised as I read these assignments of error, I don't see that it was ever raised before the Court of Appeals, whatever may have been the case in the habeas corpus proceeding.

context.speaker: James T. Carlisle
context.text: Your Honor --
